>>4427640
The reason Canines and Humans ended up becoming such good friends so early is because they're one of the few animals that can keep pace with us. Early hunter gatherers used persistence hunting, which is a tactic wolves in packs use. You're not going to outrun a spooked deer in a sprint, but if you just keep a steady pace, and keep tracking them, you can make up the difference over time, until you've exhausted the animal you're stalking and you can just all pile on the thing and break its neck or stove in its head.
They're muscles for endurance.
Cats on the other hand are typically ambush predators, and the whole tactic is reserving their energy for one big push to catch their prey.
Think of a cheetah. They're fast as fuck, but they don't keep that pace up for long.

They can't without some major genetic remodeling.

The neuron density and organization of the dog/wolf brain is superior to everything else in carnivora except for raccoons and hyenas. They even have a more primitive version of wernicke's area so they can actually understand language into thoughts and feelings, and just lack the ability to turn that process around and understand thoughts into language. The dog has the same or slightly superior peak general intelligence than a pig (of course, the average pig is going to BTFO unterdogsch like labs, shitbulls, and mastiffs in any cognitive task), with superior social comprehension, and they are extremely useful to have around as a result.

We could do better but it would mean domesticating hyenas or just leaving carnivora entirely and working with primates or taking a chance on the possibility of avians having "souls" (mammal-like self concept based on inverted causality).

Cats ARE much dumber than dogs, and they always will be. it's a neurological reality. They have fewer neurons, and the connections between them show that their brains are more oriented towards visual-motor skills. We can postulate this in the same way we can postulate a dolphin is dumber than a human, possibly smarter than a chimp. The dolphins frontal cortex is reduced, and the spindle neurons connecting distant regions of their large brain are fewer in number and less organized.

You're just easily impressed and would probably think a trained rat was smarter than an untrained border collie because your culture equates subjective metrics like career achievement and cooperation with an objective metric like cognitive capacity ("you are your job"), combined with fallacious soi-ence worship (if it has not been proven in a study, it's not that the a scientifically valid study is difficult to devise and operate to completion, it means it is not true).

>>4429684
Their muscles are built differently. Cat muscles have a lot more fast twitch muscle fiber than dogs or people do. Which is why a cat can be a lazy piece of shit 99.9% of the time and then being able to swat a bird out of the air.
People and dogs have more long muscle fibers, which are better for endurance.
We all have both kinds, and certain muscles have more of one kind than the other, depending on what they do, but you can think of cats as having spring loaded muscles. A lot more power and energy released at once, but you have to "reset" the springs before they can go again. Your endurance muscles are more like pistons, made to keep going, and have more power to give over time, but with a less steep curve.

>>4432054
About 3 yrs ago we bought ten acres which is fenced in but not dog proof. We have two large dogs that usually find their way home eventually but one likes cactus and there's lots of wildlife and neighbors dogs so we spitballed a budget of $600 and picked up the raw materials for a dog run. It's a rectangle that's about an acre total and it's great for throwing the ball and burning energy off chasing birds (one of our dogs has a crow friend). I thought it was excessive but wouldn't want to go with less than what we did. I would not let my dogs go free if there's wildlife or any chance of criminals trespassing, too much liability, but I take them on walks outside the run when I can. This is all with two dogs with established history, so who knows maybe it would be easier with a puppy if you're going that route. With some snake avoidance training I'd be more willing to let them out onto the land more I think, but I'd still consider crime an issue.

I would recommend getting it socialized asap (try to avoid getting it too sick too early) and getting it in with a reputable trainer (not Petmart) as early as the trainer will take it. I did not rear either of my dogs myself but I know neither of them were properly socialized and they both get nervous around strangers the first few times. We used to take them to to "doggy daycare" for extra socialization and training once a week before covid shut that down but now we have family and friends over whenever we can to help.

We pay A LOT for our vet, the ones that are cheap have really let me down in the past and I have been really happy with every vet I ever paid enough to care about my pets health lol. Speaking of, the dogs started getting rashes and chewing their feet when we moved in - turns out they're both allergic to something in the yard. The vet said they've had clients tear out the plants on their whole property and still not fix it, so we tried some medicated wipes once a day and they work well.

>>4430580
Probably helps more than it hurts, but snakes arent really built for combat, so if something's got one to the point of "whip your tail around and spray shit" is a valid tactic, the damage may already be done. Their primary defense is their speed and patterning acting as a sort of dazzle camo - having a bright yellow line down your back sounds like a bad idea on paper, but when that line is pointing five different directions at once as you zip into the underbrush, its hard to get a bead on where its headed.
In terms of sexing them, its harder when theyre babies, but adults do the standard snake sexual dimorphism - girls carry the babies so their bigger. Pic related, a female and her mate. Note she's gravid, so the size difference is a bit exaggerated, but only really the thickness.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>4432278
Evolution is just an explanation of the process on how various organisms adapt to survive changing environmental factors over time. The only "goal" for life is to survive and reproduce and evolution is the process that organisms go through to achieve that.
There's no higher thought process that goes through with it and thus animals are not lazy or stupid for evolving the way that they have. Koalas for instance eat eucalyptus because nothing else does and is therefore an untapped unlimited resource to be exploited. If they didn't they probably would have been outcompeted by the other marsupials they evolved alongside with. By eating eucalyptus they've carved out a niche for themselves that nothing else can encroach on.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Shitbulls are too unintelligent and unreliable to be serious protection dogs. They're bred for dogfighting. In a dogfight, the dogs try and bite and hold on to each other and only give up when the pain is too extreme. Then the humans standing by end the fight and jerk the winner off. No, that's not a figure of speech. They actually jerk the winner off. Their back legs are fucked from breeding them to splay out and dig into the dirt. So it's how they breed them.

If this happened in a protection situation, the dog would ineffectively latch on to a leg, and then be bludgeoned, stabbed, or shot. Or ignored while you were shot. Sometimes they jump up at an arm but they aren't reliable at tackling or intelligent at feinting and catching people off guard. The shitbull is just too dumb to be trained to reliably fight anything but another shitbull or a docile pet dog that poses 0 threat to anything but cats and sheep.

Every single military on earth primarily uses their dogs in the same people people use personal protection dogs and the gold standard is the belgian malinois. Agile, poweful, intelligent. The *teleports behind you* of dogs. And if they're getting hurt, they duck out and come back from another angle to keep the fight going. A pitbull just gives up, or doesn't until it dies... dogfight rules. If you put a malinois in a dogfight it would jump out of the ring and stand by your side waiting for that dumb mutt in the pit to mess with the wrong guy.

posts.com: I used to have a 50L shrimp aquarium. Lots of plants, a bunch of random inverts I intentionally added to the aquarium just cause. Some aquatic earthworms, ostracods, etc also trumpet snails. One time I had to be away for months, left instructions for water change and feeding. When I come back I find out that not only nobody did a thing but also a tiny snail got the the filter pump and jammed it. The aquarium survived with the lights on a timer and plants only and lost 20% of water due to evaporation. Nobody even replaced the lost water but the shrimp were fine. posts.name: Anonymous

>>4432037
Platys aren't nearly as good at filamentous algae. They will nibble at it but they won't outeat the growth especially if you're feeding them.
Consider blue platys tho. Most of my favorite ones are the blue or the ones with heavy pearlescence. Next year I might set up some 5s on a rack to start working on a strain.

also to answer OP thread question: there are defcon levels. 24hrs without air shouldn't be a problem for most of my tanks, there is one i would probably toss an air stone on. In summer some of my tanks would easily go a week without power.

In winter, i have some plastic bins I would fill half full, put a sponge in and place near my wood stove. I would save what fish I could but realistically with the tanks I have, not going to have time to save everyone. If it was bad enough that I was looking at ice in the tanks I would drain them down to prevent seal damage/bursting and throw as many plants as I could in with the fish in hopes of repopulating the tanks in the aftermath.

Seeing discus aquariums frozen into a block during that Texas outage was a wakeup call.

>>4432151
I got stiphodon gobys from aquaticarts in the past, and they've all been healthy. None of them lived more than about a year from the time I got them, most for 9-12mo, but I did like them. Some things you need to know:
>only the males look like that, and only when really healthy and competing with another male for some females.
>in a tank without a fuck ton of soft algae, they will starve, even if you see them actively eating algae wafers or zucchini.
>if you get them emaciated, they may starve regardless, oto-style
>they're not very good at cleaning harder algae, and won't eat black beard at all
>they are 100% wild caught, and you can't breed them in the aquarium
>they don't tolerate low aeration or dirty water

Consider peacock gudgeons as an easier and more colorful option if any of the above turn you off

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>4432397
You want less Algae? You are gonna need more living plants in your tank.
More fish=More food
More Food= Fish shitting more
More Fish Shit in the water = more nutrients in the water.
More Nutrients in the water = better growth for plant life.
If you don't have enough plants in the tank eating up all that shit in the water, Algae WILL bloom and take advantage of the nutrients. Get some floating plants. Not only will they suck up excess nuitents in the water but your Better Fish will enjoy it. I don't know if you have any kind of aqua soil under the gravel but if not get more plants that dont need to have proper soil.

Also, the moment you see your Betta make Bubble Nest be prepared. He most likely is gonna get super aggro.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>4432737
Saltwater is not that much harder if you're JUST doing fish, the fish are generally not very sensitive to the right salinity levels and are much more tolerant of slop when it comes to nutrient overload. Like when you see nitrates causing fish population crashes in the wild its because the nitrates are killing invertebrates and collapsing food chains.

But if you're doing corals, especially stony corals, it is much harder. The cost of establishing a setup is higher, all cancerous issues from algae to disease are much more of a pain in the ass to deal with when they crop up. The fish are also much bigger assholes which can be entertaining if you like that kind of thing but frustrating if you like clown car overstocked aquariums. Like the guy with his 20 platys and a betta in a 15 can easily get away with that in freshwater with a weekly water change, can't get away with that level of overstocking in saltwater. I don't know where one would get the idea that its easier/stabler when set up. Freshwater fish, even sensitive ones, are vastly more parameter tolerant.

yeah eventually i find shrimp and mts overwhelm ramshorn and bladder snails, early on they dominate the benthic population but over time they get rarer as the shrimp and livebearing snail population starts to explode. Exception is my flagfish tank because the flagfish nibble back the soft leaved, fast growing plants like pogo octopus and water sprite that the shrimp use for cover and i have a big flagfish that has acquired a taste for shrimp. >>4428063
>homeless while you work
Volunteer positions at stables are usually done on the weekend because stable hands/managers want to get their work done early, and they're not going to trust you enough to give you work that'll last the entire day. Most likely they'll ask you to muck out one or two stalls and fill up some water buckets. This is pretty light work done on days you'll be free on, you should be finished in about 2-3 hours even if you don't have experience cleaning stalls. Mind you that you won't be leading around horses or anything at the start because of the liability issues.

thank you for feeding frozen. I don't think they'd be able to smell the snakes on a different floor. We keep rats and mice in the lab, and mice are supposed to be terrified of rats since rats would eat them in the wild. They're in separate (but next door) rooms and there's never been any signs of distress. My personal pet rats don't seem to even notice food or treat smells behind doors. Although, I originally kept my rats in the same room as my dwarf hamster cages, and my hamsters started jumping going wild being really aggressive. A different floor is fine.

>>4431491
>How much time do you need to dedicate to them, if I have 2 of them and they can play with each other?
I dedicate ~1 hour every other day to spot clean, 2 hours on Sundays for a full clean, and at least an hour every other day for free roaming. WIth only 2 rats (I have 4) you'd need to clean less often.
>What's the general routine, do you let them chill out in their enclosure while you're not at home and let them out while you can look after them? In general how much space do they need?
They stay in their critter nation when I'm gone. When I'm home from work I take them out in my apartment bathroom (I put out foraging toys, cardboard box houses, pea fishing, etc) and spot clean the cage. I'll also add some more cage enrichment and make them lil salads in addition to their main diet.
>Do I have to worry about them breaking shit if I let them run around my apartment?
they chewed up my bathroom's baseboards and a hole in my door, so yes. I fixed everything with wood filler and covered the doors with draft stoppers. They can jump like 3 feet in the air and knock over items on a table if they wanted, but mine stay in the bathroom so it's never happened. They love climbing up things so be careful.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>4431491
>>4431700
>>4431549
>In general how long at a time can they be kept in their enclosure without needing to be let out?
I wouldn't go more than a week, but they won't die you go longer. I let them out everyday or every other day.
>How much of a problem is it that they shit and piss all over the place?
nah they're easily litter box trained. They run back into their cage to shit in the litter box. Males will leave tiny droplets of pee to scent mark things, but I just mop after playtime. My females literally never pee outside the cage.
>Anything else I should be aware about?
don't try to make a fence for free roaming. Mine spent the entire time trying to figure out how to knock over the barriers. Once I moved them into my bathroom, a proper enclosed space, they started actually playing with the stuff I laid out
>it looks like rats can get sick and need to the vet quite often. What's your guys' experience been with that so far?
They can get respiratory infections if you put heavily scented things near them. Make sure their bedding is fragrance free, and if you use fleece wash it with fragrance free detergent. If you get your rat from an ethical breeder, you won't have to worry as much about frequent health issues. If you get a feeder rat from the pet store, higher likelihood of cancer and other health/behavioral issues. Vet visits can be between $50 for a physical exam and $250 for neutering, so just have some money in case. I personally haven't had any issues with illness, but my rats are rescued from a lab where they're actually resistant to respiratory issues since they're born mycoplasma free. Cancer is common in all domesticated rats unfortunately, but many exotic vets are able to perform surgeries on them.

This thread is dedicated to all animals of the reptilia and amphibia classes. Topics include, but are not limited to: geckos, snakes of all kinds, frogs, salamanders, newts, turtles, tortoises, and much more. Before asking a question, do a search on the internet to see if it has been answered
Classifieds for finding breeders and products:
>morphmarket.com
>kingsnake.com
>faunaclassifieds.com
>reptilescanada.com (Canadian breeders)
>caudata.org
Most forums will have a "for sale" section on them, so look for that, especially if you have a specific herp you want. Craigslist can also be a good source for cheap aquariums, and make sure to check for any reptile expos that occur in your area.

When asking a question, make sure to include these details:
>Type and size of animal
>Enclosure dimensions
>Humidity and temperature
>Type of substrate
>The decor you use
>How often you feed
>The type of food you use
>If your animal is wild caught or captive bred
>How often you handle
>Who you bought the animal from

Other Helpful Resources

http://www.hylid.clara.co.uk/caer.htm

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Might be a dumb question but, biologically speaking, is there not a lot of significant difference between Reptiles and Amphibians? I have seen the same reptile owners keep amphibians too. And Herpetology itself seems to be concerned with both, why is that? Why aren't seperate like study of other animal classes?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>4425471
Amphibians are more basal than reptiles, in that they existed first and eventually an amphibian developed a thicker non-permeable skin, and a shell around its eggs so they wouldn't dry out and eventually didnt need to hang out in the water as much if at all. Older biology had less to do with species development and more to do with "what does it look like, where does it live, and what does it do" though, so they just kind got lumped in together.
From a petkeeping perspective, the care of reptiles and amphibians is pretty similar (diets are similar in a lot of cases, need to build a little environment for them whose parameters are generally similar) so there's some crossover there.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>4425471
Amphibians and reptiles are divided by as many years of evolution as amphibians and mammals, and that is more years than the division between mammals and reptiles. But their ways of life and their metabolism are less diverged from those times than are mammals or the archosaur subgroup of Reptiles.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>4426940
colubrids in general are more active than boids or pythons so it's less "here is a big sock filled with jello, it might climb on you" and more "hold on to this rope that constantly wants to move forward." treadmilling and allowing the snake to weave around your hand and arm is the name of the game. He is always going to want to go SOMEWHERE and/or investigate SOMETHING so will probably not be down for chill hangouts.
In terms of handling tolerance, even after you get him used to you being around and even get him to the point where he'll climb onto you voluntarily, if they dont want to go somewhere they dont want to go somewhere. The goal in that case is to wire into his head that nothing bad happens when you pick him up, and the best way to do that is to pick him up (standard snake handling rules apply - confident gentle scoop, first third to half of the body, dont hesitate or move too fast because either looks like predator behavior), inspect him a little bit, then let him go back inside the enclosure and leave him to his business for the rest of the day, repeating every day to every other day until the snake is just like "oh yeah okay it's you," then do it like once or twice a week or so to reinforce.
Note you'll want to do this when he's awake and active, ripping up a hide and grabbing a snake is a real good way to convince a snake you're going to kill it.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>4426857
Morphmarket. I got him for about $1300 at age 4 months. There's two varieties of emerald tree boas... amazon basin and northern. Amazon Basin have a continuous stripe down their back and are longer (7-9 foot) with a more calm demeanor and attitude. These are the super expensive ones people collect and breed morphs of like ball pythons.

Northern variety are a little shorter (5-6 foot range) and have a worse attitude. They can still be worked with but its a lot more effort. They have a broken pattern down their back and aren't usually collected as much. This results in northern variety being cheaper.

Mine is a Northern, because a captive bred baby will cost between $1000-2000 for a northern, but $6-10000 for an amazon basin. I just didnt find the extra cost worth it. My little guy is great despite being northern. The breeder I got him from was real small time guy but they are certainly out there.

But also definitely make sure whatever you buy is captive bred, not captive born. Ask for pictures of the parents and whatever information you can get to try to verify they are actually captive bred. A lot of dealers will put "CB" so people think that means captive bred, when its actually captive born. These are just still wild ETBs that have had their eggs stolen and born in captivity. This doesn't help with their temperament. They need to be born of captive parents, preferably of parents who were themselves captive bred.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>4429933
To be honest, if there were any animal you could get that would make a sizable enough difference in a roach population to help with an infestation, you'd already know about it, in much the same way as you know that people keep cats around barns to get rid of mice, or terriers for ratting. Most bug-eating lizards that would eat roaches in a way that would actually help with that (chasing after them, running up wall, etc) would only do one or two a day at max, if that, which means you'd need an impractical number of lizards to make any sort of real impact. Just stick to commercially available poisons and traps, and make your house a spotlessly clean food and water desert - no food items outside of airtight containers, no trash or garbage inside the house for long enough to attract insects, keep crevices behind furniture as clean as you possibly can. If you live in an apartment you're more or less fucked, because they can and will just move elsewhere and then come right back, but anything you can do to make your area inhospitable to them will help keep them at bay.

Get some guppies, or better yet heterandria formosa, and cherry/ghost shrimp to live with them. Then feed them sinking pellets. posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>4428091
That's an odd categorization. The ones who don't care about the breed are good people, while the ones who care are not? I don't see how that makes sense. Dog owners should understand the breeds they own and care about their working purpose. They should try to give their dog the kind of a lifestyle that dog was bred for. A person who doesn't research the breed they own doesn't sound like a good dog owner to me.

Either way, whether you love or hate dogs isn't an indicator of what kind of a person you are.
Someone who loves dogs might love them so much that they become a misanthrope and consider dogs more important than humans. They might become a hoarder and end up with so many dogs that they can't take care of them all properly. They might cover up bite incidents out of fear that their dogs would get taken away and euthanized. They might bring aggressive dogs into public spaces and put other people in danger.
Someone who hates dogs might hate them because they were bitten by one. They might live in a location where feral dogs shit everywhere, spread diseases, kill livestock and attack people. They might have lost a loved one in a dog attack.

Even if you love dogs, there are plenty of ways you might end up causing harm to either dogs or other people. And even if you hate dogs, that's not a bad thing if you simply avoid them instead of trying to hurt them.
Loving or hating dogs isn't the litmus test for being a good person. How you treat other people and animals is what matters.

I don't know it it's true. We know males of various mysticeti species sing to determine who's bigger and stronger. But sometimes, humpback whale bulls fight so unless I have footage to disprove it, I'll assume blue whale bulls fight with massive fluke slaps or ramming the opponent by lifting themselves out of the water and dropping onto them.
Head ramming is, by the way, not possible for them because their jaws are so fragile. Blue whales also have an organ between the tips of their lower jaws that helps them determine a bait ball density and if it's even worth opening their gigantic maws for it. They use up a lot of energy to fill their mouths and press out the water. If the bait ball is not big enough to over compensate that energy loss, the whale won't even bother with it.

>>4430499
Yes. Getting pair of bonded cats, or kittens that will grow up together if brought home at the same time, is considered a good choice. However getting only one cat is not a bad thing; just make sure to give it plenty of attention when you are back home, play with it every day and let it take part in your activities, when possible.
A small house will necessarily have to be enriched with at least one big cat tree, cardboard box(es), a cat tunnel and if possible wall shelves. And of course toys.
Remember, cats need to use vertical space too.
I am for adopting at cat shelters, but if you are oriented for a specific breed do thorough research and select a reliable breeder.

I'm not sure why the other spot is barren but it doesn't really concern me. I'm planting a small pollinator garden this spring, or rather adding onto what I have. I also put some Trout Lily (erythronium americanum) bulbs into a pot a few days ago hoping to sprout them but I ordered them a few months ago and I'm worried I let them dry out too long. Unlike a bulb proper they don't have a hard outer layer which helps to retain moisture. I ended up soaking them for about 30 minutes and putting them into some potting soil on a windowsill and I'll just hope for the best.

hi /plant/ please post 1 tip that you wish you knew before starting your herb garden
tired of paying out of my ass for dried basil and oregano

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>4431957
Seeds in plant trays. Don't direct sow. Most culinary herbs are in the lamiaceae family and they have tiny seeds and seedlings that take forever to get started. It's way easier to start those things now in trays indoors and baby them until they get big enough for transplanting. Grow more than you think you'll need. Having too many plants is a good problem to have.

>>4396491
My guess is that South American Corvids aren't well suited to the climate/environment of Patagonia. Looking at the "List of birds of Brazil" Wikipedia page, it appears the only Corvids in Brazil belong to the genus Cyanocorax. A large portion of the range in the Corvidae range map seems to be due to the range of the genus Corvus (which makes up 1/3 of Corvid species) and according to its Wikipedia page it occurs "on all temperate continents except South America". Corvus would likely do quite well in temperate SA but it appears that Central America is the barrier preventing them from reaching it (I think Corvus corax is the closest in the Americas but its range stops in Nicaragua).

There are three reasons.

>From an evolutionary perspective the North American crows originated in what is now Asia.
>The North American crow species have not moved south, probably because there is no reason to do so.
>There is ample competition from Mexico southwards, with a number of families of birds which have evolved to occupy a similar ecological niche as crows, the Caracaras for instance, of which there are eleven species. This competition led the corvid lineages that did venture south into niches unlike other corvids, rainforest frugivores like parrots.

Great American Interchange didn't always mean that North American species outcompeted South American ones. Think of how successful possums are, for example.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>4430482

I think they're still smart, not as intelligent as larger Northern corvids like ravens and crows, but still as intelligent as jungle psittacids (another high EQ bird family). They consist of 15 species of jay in two genera, Cyanolyca and Cyanocorax. Cyanolyca is more basal to all American jays (Cyanocoracinae), while Cyanocorax species are usually larger and derive from the same lineage as NA magpie-jays and the Mexican brown jay. Cyanocoracine jays are suited for wooded environments and carry the same jay synapomorphies, so when they expanded into Central America after the continents collided, they were the group of corvids that did best in the Amazon basin and other South American neotropical ecoregions. However, like was stated in this thread, South American bird fauna were very competitive, and when North American lineages other than corvids expanded south, it was caracaras that dominated the ground-walking opportunistic niches that corvids enjoyed in the Northern Hemisphere.

posts.com:
inside when we leave. so about 6 months ago we adopted a 2 year old female spayed whippet mix named kiwi. she came to us not house trained. she used to go into the other room and pee, sometimes poop. she was a very shy and easily distractable pooper and peer. sometimes it would be a half hour till she found a spot outside. we take her on average 3 20 mimute walks a day. she would also whine and yip when we would leave.
we would reward her for peeing and pooping outside, reward her for not peeing/pooping inside when we leave, and also reward her for not hooting and hollering when we fake leave. we still do the first two of those because why not. currently, she has not pooped inside for 5 months, hasn’t whined when we leave for 4ish months, and quickly pees and poops when we take her out or is let out in the yard. since its cold rn and she doesnt like it, we have been letting her out in the yard mostly 5-6 times a day when someone is home. there are usually 1-2 days a week where both me and my gf are gone all day, for about 7-8 hours. she surprisingly does well with that. but usually i work M-F and my gf works R, S, and Su. i get off around 3-4, she gets off 4:30. however, maybe about once or twice a month since we got her she will pee when we leave. not always, and she hadn’t done it for a whole month and a half. at first we were mostly crate training her. but she would pee inside of it. she would then kick over her bed and then sleep on the floor of the crate. or if we were sleeping and she was in the crate, she would pee, then whine for us. she had a really good streak so we decided to let her free roam a single room while we are gone. she was doing great for a long time. but this month she has peed on the floor twice. she has bones, a chewable duck, kong, and a ring shaped chew toy. she loves chewing. but shes also a very sleepy dog desu. she gets pooped out from playing with me alot quicker than any dog ive had. shes very lazy basically.

I’m not reading all that op
>dog keeps peeing
A couple of strategies to try to fix this
>does it have a favorite spot to pee?
Buy training pads and try to have it pee there
Gradually move the pad elsewhere like outside, since it smells it’s scent to go potty
>do you have a water bowl out?
If so, only have the water bowl out at certain times, especially keep it out before you all go to sleep
You can also replace water with ice so it drinks less but feels refreshed still
I assume you walk it a lot so keep doing that and reinforce it with treats
Training older dogs to not pee indoors is extrmely hard
They’re animals that need to learn at puppyhood
It thinks what it’s doing is the right think
You just need to rewire it’s brain

I had a vision in my sleep last night. As distinguished from a dream which is mere sorting and cataloguing of the day's events by the subconscious. This was a vision, fresh and clear as a stream in Central Kalimantan- the mind revealing itself to itself. In my vision, I was on the veranda of a vast feeding platform, a Peron Makan of some fantastic proportion.
There seemed to emanate from it a light from within - this gleaming radiant jungle. I had known this place. I had in fact been born and raised there. This was my first return, a reunion with the deepest wellsprings of my being. Wandering about, I was happy that the forest had been immaculately maintained. There had been planted a number of additional trees, but in a way it blended so seamlessly with the original canopy, one would never detect any difference. Returning to the jungle's grand treescape, there came a knock from above. Budi was standing there. He was happy and care-free, clearly living a life of deep harmony and joy. We embraced - a warm and loving embrace, nothing withheld. We were in this moment one. My vision ended. I awoke with a tremendous of optimism and confidence in pongos and their future.

IDK if this is the right thread because I don't frequent /an/, but I have a burning question: Based on what's known about Hypsilophodon, is it accurate for it to be this funny chicken that spits acid?
https://isle.fandom.com/wiki/Hypsilophodon

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>4394215
That complex feathering is probably far beyond the filaments and proto-feathers that actually would have adorned the animal so it would have looked more like a plucked turkey.
>spits acid
We'll probably never be able to know something like that, though maybe the animal's teeth would show the effects of continuous exposure to stomach acid. It probably wouldn't be used as a blinding agent, but there are a number of birds that vomit on themselves or vomit on their attackers as a defensive mechanism. So It might have been possible that Hysilophodon could have used vomit oil in a similar way as Fulmar chicks or it could use a mix of spit and vomit to try and blind animals similar to camels.
Without any evidence of these behaviors in Hypsilophodon I can't really call it accurate, but it's not impossible for it to have used vomit as an anti-predator mechanism.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>4400460
You want to qualify these questions:
>What level of nervous system do they have? Unicellular, Cnidarianesque, Molluskesque, Tetrapodesque?
>Are they amorphous or semirigid? If they're amorphous, how do they protect themselves and navigate the world? How do they manipulate the world? Semirigid will have a much easier time here.
>How did they attain intelligence and tool use, and how well-versed in it are they? Are they more intelligent and well-situated for whatever niche they inhabit, or are they really good at using tools but not the biggest brainiac?
My personal recommendation is to go with a cephalopod-esque intelligence and make them deep-sea dwellers that can contort their bodies easily but discovered tool use as an excellent way to preserve them and their kin. You can easily make whalefalls/driftwood equivalents more common on their home world for native materials and a source for them to tread upwards. Bonus: deep-sea dwelling creatures often survive trips to the surface easily, so it would make them look even more blobbish but without any risks to their functionality. It would also give them precedence for wearable devices or containers for respiration or similar so you can move forward with your initial idea if you so choose. Just remember to not make them literal octopus/squids. Try searobins+blobfish as the basis, maybe.

>>4400460
I have an idea though it's evolutionarily dodgy imo.

First off, we have real slime life forms on earth: slime molds. Despite being single celled organisms that don't have anything even close to a brain they're apparently capable of some degree of cognition (see: https://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2016/04/160427081533.htm?trendmd-shared=0). Even better for you, they're capable of fusing together into super-cells and apparently can share that knowledge (see: https://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2016/12/161221090246.htm)
I hope you're serious about it not being 100% realistic because here's were it gets a little dodgy, lets pretend that enough of them fuse together allows to develop something approaching or even surpassing human intelligence either with this weird cell memory or using millions of cell nuclei as some kind of central nervous system or maybe having some kind of unique organelles to function as a cns. Either way, they're still basically a living puddle of snot so they'd need some kind of powered exoskeleton to do much of interest but I'm not sure how they'd make one in the first place regardless of what their environment is like. Maybe they got some help from some other species and have since gained independence.

Started to play around with domestication yesterday. Vucum's ch'ceri means 'friend of the people' and is a very trusting creature. The two things on the left are scrapped concepts because I feel like they're not very creative. Bottom one was supposed to be a domesticated later evolution form of the one above. I've been thinking about how aquatic mammals could come across a large, distant island that no other large mammals have yet colonized, and re-evolve a terrestrial lifestyle (nevermind the awkward wobbling pinnipeds already do). I have three main questions about this idea:

- What pressures would there be for pinnipeds (the most likely candidate; cetaceans would be too anatomically awkward) to evolve terrestriality? Sure, with little to no competition, they can radiate like hell with all the new food sources give a couple million years, but what would convince a population of them to totally leave the water?

- I've noticed that practically all aquatic mammals (besides otters, I guess) have blubber. Why is that - how necessary is it? I can see it being necessary for cold temperate waters, but what about sunbaked tropical coastal waters? Would it be possible for a population of pinnipeds to become "skinny" again if they keep to warm tropical waters?

- How plausible is it for the hind flippers to become more "leg-like" and aid in terrestrial locomotion?

posts.name: Anonymous

>>4427724
Adding to this anon: mammals are endothermic. They lose body temperature very quickly in water, even in tropical regions. That's why the Amazon river dolphin still has 4cm of blubber. There was a video of stranded common dolphins that explained that they lose heat much faster on land than in water and once they started to shiver, the rescue team had to spray them with seawater. Don't know how relevant this is but whatever.

He needs a new home really. Nothing crazy, but like at least a 5 gallon, and a cheap filter, either hang on or sponge, and a cheap heater. Gravel or sand in the bottom and some more decorations would be a plus. This plastic plant can rip their fins so use discretion when adding them.

Really he doesn't look to be in the worst shape. He's a crown tail so his fins are supposed to have that effect. That's not to say he wouldn't benefit from a better setup. You could probably find all the stuff on Craigslist or Facebook marketplace for dirt cheap. posts.name: Anonymous

>>4432089
Probably only thing he needs is heat. Being in closet is ok. Betta in the wild lives in murky pools so they used to being dark. More natural than bright light constantly blinding. Most important thing to betta is food proper warmth and to show gills now and again for the exercise. If you want you may put in a dried banana leaf. It will turn the water a little brown like a tea but it helps to keep away illness.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>4432089
>>4432142
Any uneaten food left sitting is a bad sign. Overfeeding + no biological filtration + no maintenance = toxic environment.

It's a little controversial here but you CAN keep a betta healthy and happy in a small 1G tank, but the chances are the people who get these super tiny enclosures are not maintaining them well enough or at all for this to happen. 5G is of course a much better size and people who commit to this usually show some investment which means generally better care.

These people obviously don't give a shit about the fish, and pets in general require more responsibility than practically anyone ever suspects, fish included. Everyone says take it in yourself, however that's not fair to you. It is wiser to surrender that fish to a fish store that takes care of fish (not one that keeps them in cups) or to the ASPCA or some other similar organization. It is free to do.

That fish doesn't seem like it's been there that long so it's got a good chance of recovery. Betta can live 3-5 years with good care. It's a teachable moment in many ways but I don't know what your relationship is with that part of your family so it is something you must decide yourself.

posts.com:
>>4432717
sponge filters are air pumps with an attached sponge. Any aquarium filter is better than nothing really. Bigger tank will make things much easier concerning water quality.
Also fundamental is an aquarium heater. If you are not in a rush you can order the filter and heater off of aliexpress for around 20-25 usd, if you order from amazon it's slightly more expensive but you should still be in the 35-40 USD range. Forget the banana leaf, in a small tank like the current one with no filtration you risk adding more bioload by it rotting

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>4429489
>What's the best litter brand?
depends what your cat will use and what you're willing to compromise on. i'm partial to okocat.
Is it actually bad for cats?
https://animalwellnessmagazine.com/clay-litter-harming-cat/
https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/32096459
https://journals.plos.org/plosone/article?id=10.1371/journal.pone.0014647
https://crittersandme.com/blog/clumping-clay-kitty-litters-a-deadly-convenience/
https://animalwellnessmagazine.com/scents/
https://www.petpoisonhelpline.com/blog/essential-oils-cats/
if you can't pour it without holding your breath or turning your face away, then your cat is breathing in fine particulate matter that lungs aren't designed to handle every time he uses the litter. if silica, then eventual fibrosis.
if it can clog yer terlet, it can clog your cat.
if it's highly absorbent outside your cat, it'll be highly absorbent inside your cat. if dry kibble accounts for any significant portion of his diet, he's already chronically dehydrated.
if you can detect a fragrance, whatever's producing it will get inhaled into your cat's system as an irritant at best and a toxin at worst.
if you use a covered litter box, it's further exacerbating all of the above.
cheap and convenient seldom comes without cost.

>>4428507

Explains why theropods got so massive and macroraptorial so quickly in the Jurassic - if the given stock of prey species was dominated by massive sauropodomorphs (which evolved to huge sizes as a defence mechanism against theropods), and the ratio of ornithopods was lower, while other ornithischians were evolving armoured defences which require greater specialisation to get through, the clearest niche to fill would be to get bigger and bigger along with the prey. The colossal carnosaurs of the Early to Mid Cretaceous - the carcharodontosaurs - were the apogee of this development, evolved to hunt the giant titanosaur species that roamed across the Southern Hemisphere during the break-up of Gondwana. Only when ornithischians eclipsed sauropods in the mid-late Cretaceous did the specialisation of the giant carnosaurs become their gradual undoing, as they were themselves outcompeted by smaller, more robust abelisaurids and tyrannosaurids, which were better adapted for hunting new ornithischian stock. And then, only when ornithischians became truly massive themselves in the Late Cretaceous (giant hadrosaurs and chasmosaurine ceratopsians), did tyrannosaurids catch up in the form of giants like Tarbosaurus and Tyrannosaurus.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>4430395

>tyrannosaur competition causing their extinction

I misspoke, I wasn't necessarily trying to say that tyrannosaurs outcompeted carnosaurs directly, but rather than whatever bio-ecological shift that saw a change in the ratio of prey species in the Northern Hemisphere from more sauropods to more ornithischians was also what saw the decline of absolutely massive carnosaurs like the carcharodontosaurs, and opened up new niches for smaller robust theropods like abelisaurs and tyrannosaurs. Obviously it's never going to be as cut and dry as that, but we can theorise that the gradual decline of the carcharodontosaurs and their disappearance from the fossil record by the Cenomanian (when they truly reached their greatest sizes with Giganotosaurus, Mapusaurus and Carcharodontosaurus) could be connected to the shift in sauropod populations, and that shift also eventuated the success and diversity of abelisaurids and tyrannosaurids in the last 25 million years of the Cretaceous, both in the Northern and Southern Hemispheres. We can perhaps theorise some large scale biogeographical shift that meant that carcharodontosaurs, which were specialised to be giant apex predators hunting the juveniles of the huge titanosaurs (or potentially forming packs and hunting adults), could no longer cope. Usually this kind of specialisation is a double edged sword - you're king of the castle while things are stable, at the highest trophic level, but when there are ecological shifts, migrations or other environmental factors, your specialisation can be a handicap. The ancestral lineages of abelisaurs and tyrannosaurs were most likely generalists, and when the Mid Cretaceous transitioned to the Late Cretaceous, it seems that they were the ones to benefit.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>4430395
>>4430432

Again, like you said, the Cenomanian seems to exhibit shifts in the fossil record when it comes to the dominance of different large theropod lineages. The spinosaurids also thin out of the fossil record at this time, and they were clearly very specialised compared to other tetanurans.
The megaraptorans are a bit of a wild card, if they were indeed allosauroids, then they could be an argument for smaller, lightweight carnosaurs with long grasping forelimbs surviving where massive carcharodontosaurs could not.
Maybe this biogeographical transition and faunal turnover, if it did happen, could be linked to the Bonarelli anoxia event, which was related to the development of large igneous provinces across the equator due to marine transgression and the continued break up of Gondwanaland. Sea levels rose, choking littoral and delta ecosystems which supported spinosaurids, but also potentially shrinking the floodplains that the giant titanosaurs would have relied upon as nesting grounds. The carbon cycle disturbance also interrupted the marine oxygen cycle, leading to 500,000 years of decline in marine biodiversity, as reflected in the fossil record with reductions in plankton and foraminifer biodiversity. The increase in average water depth would have seawater to become less eutrophic in shallow, epicontinental seas, and this brought about the extinction of the ichthyosaurs and pliosaurs, just like you said. Then, over the following strata, mosasaurs grow to gigantic sizes and dominant the interior seaways of North America and Europe, and the epicontinental seas around Zealandia. So there was definitely a faunal turnover in the ocean, which may have had analogues on land. Something was going on.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>4430433
>>4430395

So my argument is not that one group outcompeted the other, but rather that some ecological, biogeographical or general environmental shift meant that carcharodontosaurs couldn't keep up, and other lineages of theropods eventually, after many millions of years, grew to fill the new apex predators niches, this time hunting ceratopsians and hadrosaurs.
I think the last giant carnosaur in North America we can see in the fossil record was Acrocanthosaurus, which existed in a transitional marginal floodplain ecosystem around the rim of the growing Western Interior Seaway, and was extinct by the Cenomanian. Obviously fossilisation means we generally have a bias towards floodplain ecosystems in the Early Cretaceous (sedimentation), but clearly something was happening in the Northern Hemisphere in the time that set the scene for the larger changes by the end of the Cretaceous.
However, you're right that there are big terrestrial gaps in the Mid Cretaceous fossil record that mean that this is all purely hypothetical. A giant late-surviving carnosaur from the last 25 million years of the Cretaceous could be discovered that would throw up more questions.

>>4417092
Most of the slower growing more arid new world species are supposed to tolerate it pretty well, basically your Aphonopelma, Grammostola and Brachypelma and probably some of the less common genera from similar climates. That said, you always want to do it as close to the ground as possible because they're extremely fragile and you also want to make sure to check the temperament before you try to handle by gently touching the animal with a brush or something.

Overall I'd still recommend against it though, the animal gets nothing out of it and there's always a pretty significant risk of killing it if anything goes wrong

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>4422334
Their availability nowadays isn't so bad, but I guess their prices vary a lot between Europe and the US. In EU you can get L2 for 12-16€ each, while I've seen Americans ask for like $40 which I guess discourages people from buying larger groups to breed themselves and help making them more accessible.

I think their care is managable if you already have some mantis experience and are dedicated, but it's a species where it's really best to go all in and keep a group in a large setup and eventually try to breed them. Throughout the nymph stages they aren't even that bad, they just need it hot and dry in a well-ventilated cage. Once they are subadult it gets more tricky because they need a lot higher humidity and the final molts are just generally risky and ultimately involve some luck to not go badly, which is why keeping a bunch of them helps so that a mismolt doesn't completely screw you over. When I kept them I self-built netcages with branches glued to the top for better gripping during molts, that worked quite well. Breeding just didn't work out for me because I ended up with only one male, who grew faster than the females and was already a geriatric by the time they became ready to mate and he couldn't connect despite his willingness to do so.

Other empusids like Blepharopsis mendica and Gongylus gongylodes are cool alternatives that are less expensive and demanding, but somewhat similar to them.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>4428948
If you can drop daytime humidity to about 50-60% you could do a group of Phyllocrania paradoxa. Very frequently available, very easy to care for, calm and low cannibalism risk in a sizable tank with good structures and enough food. The females also can have a variety of colorations.

The rainforest species that can be kept communally are on the smaller side, some pretty hard to care for and possibly also hard to get, maybe not even available in the US. They would ideally also have some degrees higher temperature. Those would be mantids like Haania sp., Stenophylla lobivertex, Astyliasula phyllopus, or Ceratomantis sp.. Odontomantis would also work and should be more commonly available, but they're really small as adults and pretty basic looking mantids after all.

Not for groupkeeping, but as a bigger, exotic looking rainforest species you could also consider a Deroplatys desicatta/trigonodera/lobata/truncata or Parablepharis kuhlii. They look really nice and at least for mantis standards their lifespans tend to be a bit on the longer side. A slightly higher temp range of about 77-81F would be good for those though.

Also make sure that your tank's ceiling is covered in mesh, mantids will frequently strife towards higher spots and will end up hanging from the top in captivity a lot of the time. That also gives them convenient space for molting.

Pretty good. They won't understand the concept of nukes and they won't resent humans for what happened. Many of them will learn to find food on their own even if tons of humans die and can't take care of them. But they've also been bred to be companions for a very long time, and they'll probably be happy to be offered that kind of life.

However, you've got a purebred GSD stray in your picture. If the nukes dropped more than a decade or two ago, the odds of encountering a purebred GSD as a stray would be slim. Dogs that live and reproduce in the wild will generally become brown/orange/yellow mutts after a certain amount of generations. If you encounter a purebred dog in a world that's been in a post-apocalyptic status quo for a while, it must've belonged to someone who was so devoted to the breed that they continued breeding those dogs even after the nuclear holocaust.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>4417067
A strong rat trap, not one of those wimpy plastic ones. Peanut butter, rancid if you have some, they just can't help themselves. If you're a compassionate soul, set them (get at least half a dozen) when you're around and wait to hear the snap, then immediately go over to it and bash the poor things head in with a heavy object (I use a big automotive wrench). Oftentimes the trap breaks the lower spine, not the neck and causes the little vermin a great deal of pain before it finally dies. It is absolutely necessary to kill them as soon as you can, and in my mind, if you must kill, do it quickly and cleanly as you can. If you can see one, there are probably several you don't see, so keep setting traps until it's been days since you got one. Let me reiterate, it is absolutely imperative that you kill all of them as soon as you can. If you hesitate or show mercy, not only will they fuck your world, you will end up having to kill far far more of them in the future. I am listening to rat scratches in the ceiling right now. I didn't have the heart to kill a rat, and now I've been killing scores of it's descendants every week for the past six months. The whole property is lousy with them. I'm like mouse Hitler at this point lol. Don't be like me anons.

>>4428848
Everything you listed applies to pic-related as well. They have slit pupils and large whiskers because they are naturally nocturnal animals. They have large tails because they are for warmth protection, not balance. Saying they are more 'closer' to cats than wolves are to cats are (in terms of convergence) is true, but it's a fallacy. Nobody is saying that lions are closer to wolves than African wild cats are because they are larger and live in groups, even though this is also a true statement. It's this type of comparison which I think is inane.

>>4428851
Foxes aren't solitary in the same way wild cats are. Wild cats spend practically their entire adult life alone, as nomads, and their communication with others of their species mostly being done with territory and scent marking, and their physical encounters mostly involve fighting disputes or mating. Foxes and tanuki are social animals that live in groups, and typically have an established den or living area. They also are characteristically known for their social aspect of playing with each other for fun, wagging their tails, and their high range of vocalizations (barking, howling, whining, etc) which they use to communicate with each other. Foxes are naturally possess canine-like movement and behavior due to their biology. Just look at footage like this >>4427716 and tell me you can't see the difference.

>>4428871
Crossing breeds willy nilly often ends badly. Unpredictable temperaments and health problems. They can be hard to adopt out, or worse, they become a trend and the wrong people want to adopt them. The Goldendoodle is an infamous example.

If you're willing to keep the entire litter just for science or whatever then it's probably fine, albeit still a health gamble. But legit breeders won't do these gimmicky pairings for clients because it's usually bad for the dogs. BYBs on the other hand don't give a shit and specialize in boutique dog mutants for the cash. See toadlines for the most extreme example. Even relatively normal looking dogs can have genetic time bombs from poor breeding practices.

>>4429546
There is no consensus on that sort of thing. Scientists differ widely in their philosophies regarding that sort of thing. Some think that returning an ecosystem to a historical state is better, while others focus more on how an ecosystem functions overall rather than the 'uniqueness' of the species involved in that ecosystem.

So if a captive bred species X performs the exact same functions in the ecosystem as a historical/wild species X it is fine. Or even replace with a different species that does exactly the same thing. E.g. a fly that has sligtly different shaped penis but still does the same thing as a different species.

>One theory explaining the highly unsual habit of H. zschokkei and its fellow myxosporeans invokes the cancers of cnidarians. Ah, the old HeLa/transmissible dog cancer dynamic strikes again. This reminds me how any animal, technically, just depends on its germ line. It sounds trivial, but it becomes more fascinating the more think about it: we ultimately only depend on the genetic code that belongs to the sperm/egg. Meaning if some cosmic ray strikes you gonads, all your descendants will have that change (simplified). If the entire rest of the body receives a trillion cosmic rays, your progeny will not care and not be affected. You -- the person that is you -- literally just sources from ball cells.
As said, it sounds trivial, but also strange.

Some people say pets are parasites. But this is because they don’t understand what the pet actually does or how (in fact they are antisocial and low empathy and never will). The pet replaces them. The obligatory friend who is just a friend and does very little, but highly social people need that no strings attached relationship to stay sane and evolving to lack the need for one at all would make them worse in other ways. Pets are a symbiote that allows us to remain highly social and replace potentially dangerous and resource intensive non-productive humans with something exponentially safer and cheaper. Objectively less unneeded human contact lessens your risk of being killed or stolen from. All of your human friends should be productive enough to make up for that risk, but that creates stressful obligations and friendships that can never be relied on. The useless friend is the best one to confide in and rely on just to fulfill your instincts.

They are an inevitable and essential part of an efficient high trust society but they must be that. Friends, fwbs. Not children. Or they stop being a symbiote. It’s like your gut flora moving to your body cavity - nope!

>>4400543
If you want ducks, just handcatch them. Feed them, gain their trust. Give them bread, first some floating bits, when you have them within reach, squish the bread so that it sinks.

When they start diving for it, throw a few sinking pieces, grab them when they stick their heads under.

I used to do this to stop the ducks from trying to eat my fishing bait, just hold one (male for best results-) upside down for the rest to see. Then release, no problems for the rest of the day.

Or keep them, free pets/food.

I’ve owned like every breed of domestic duck and also some exotic ones like mandarins and wood ducks. Never had an issue with aggression. In domestic ducks drakes will only pick on other birds because they’re trying to rape them. They’re certainly a lot more docile to each other than chickens.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>4400543
They have random personalities and males will fight like roosters will.
We have a male that was raised with chickens and he fucking despises our chickens and will chase them. Another male call duck is tiny as hell but will try and nip at your ankles. The rest are pretty chill.
Depending on the drake you will need 2-4 hens for him. Otherwise they will literally breed the poor females to death. Although sometimes you can get away with one to one ratios.
Call ducks especially pair off well, but don't like swimming like other ducks and prefer just to splash in shallow puddles and dishes.
Our one bossy female call duck is pretty funny since she will quack very loudly if her flock gets more than a few feet from her. They will then circle back to her.
Also if they aren't making a nest ducks will lay eggs wherever they fucking want. So keep that in mind.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>4403365
Ours did pretty well nesting, but we never let them hatch since we had enough birds at the time. Only thing to keep in mind is to make sure their area is fairly good size.
When the ground is wet and muddy ducks will bury their beaks in them and look for bugs. Problem is that this will add up and soon their pen will be full of small holes everywhere. Because they are some of the largest ducks if they step in one of those holes they can hurt their legs. Ducks have very fragile legs and larger ones especially.
We have an old drake that hurt his leg and doesn't move much. Honestly surprising he has made it this long.

>>4427492
>is it possible for fish populations to recover while we still maintain high levels of wild fishing?
Depends on the species, Some species have a fast lifecycle and are highly prolific but others take a long time to reproduce. I think the future lies in protecting aquatic habitats and breeding grounds so the prolific species can continue being abundant for extraction combined with aquaculture so we can make not so prolific species more prolific by reducing mortality and other factors. There is also selective breeding and GMOs and we might produce for example tuna that grows faster and taste better.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Doing my dissertation on this right now. It's an absolute fucked industry. Salmon farming is the big one. The problem is literally every sea pen of salmon is infested with salmon lice that essentially eat the fish alive until it's body gives up. Because the salmon are so packed together it's like a breeding factory for lice which can then drift out of the pens and infect wild salmon.
Farmed salmon get treatment for the lice ( which is also fucked. Thermolicers are hot water treatments that essentially micro cook the salmon while alive to kill the lice), but wild salmon obvs get nothing and 1-2 lice will kill a juvenile salmon easy. Wild salmon populations are essentially non recoverable because salmon farming won't end bc it's too tasty.
Profits are plummeting for some companies rn because of literally microjellyfish floating in and killing half the stock, so salmon prices are probably gonna spike soon.
Also, wild fact. Salmon farms in Scotland eat more food mass per day than the human population of the entire UK. And less fun, salmon farms were started to reduced wild fishing, but 2/3 of salmon food is wild caught fish. So what's the fucking point.

Sure, maybe. I'm not claiming to know.
Koalas, like wombats, have a backwards-facing pouch -- which is also downwards-facing in the case of the koala.
This is apparently because they descend from a common ancestor that burrowed like a wombat and didn't want dirt in its pouch.
The koala, though, has evolved a sphincter muscle around the top (bottom) of its pouch so that the baby koalas don't fall out 150 feet up a gum tree.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Worked in a pig farm.
Honestly my favourite job yet. I did come home everyday smelling like shit, waking up at 3AM was annoying and some of the coworkers were assholes.
But otherwise, loved it. If I still had my notes with all the schedules it would be like this:
>4AM, prepare milk for the piglets and feed them
>5-6AM scrape the shit in the piglets kennel
>6AM Sows feeding time, give them and their piglets vitamins and feed, scrape the shit as the sows wake up and get fed through the automatic feeder
>7AM some free time, go to the office to have a coffee, read a book etc...
>8AM Go srape/wash away (depended on the temperature of the day) shit from the not-yet-pregnant sows hall
>9AM Go feed piglets and scrape their shit again
>10AM Go feed the momma pigs and their piglets, scrape their shit, again. (Yes, a lot of shit scraping)
>11AM all work done for today and all thats left is to wait for the afternoon shift to come in and update them about what happened that day and I could go home.
There we a lot of cats, as rats were common (hunted them with a plank), my 2 favourite cats was a small black cat I called Lil' Nigga and a Cripple for being a bit crippled (cattarct in one eye and fucked up ear), they both smelled constanly like shit.
Yes, I did have to deal with my fair share of dead pigs. The piglets were easy, just chuckem in a bucket and done. When swines died that was a problem, they are heavy, and you have to drag them outside so you can actually load them up on the tractor.
Pic related

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Buy some carbon dioxide and try inhaling it. I did this while I was trying to make carbogen, a mixture of co2 and o2 that can make you hallucinate. I had some success but on most attempts it was very difficult and painful to use. If you put too much co2 into it it's fucking painful (you want maybe 50/50 co2/o2).

Inhaling pure co2 would be even more painful.

Killing creatures with co2 is not humane, nowhere near. Try inhaling a balloon of co2... it's fucking painful. Now imagine killing yourself with co2... nightmare.

Argon would be better... more expensive though. Point is, the gas needs to be heavier than air, both co2 and argon are.

Nitrous oxide (laughing gas) would be pretty humane as it's an anaesthetic. During that experimental phase when I tried carbogen I used to do nitrous a lot, was very fun.

If you kill mice with co2 they show massive agitation.

Yea... anytime someone shows you killing creatures with co2 be aware the animals are suffering, big time. co2 makes your body system think it's suffocating (that's why carbogen works, the body releases excess oxygen, while the high level of oxygen in carbogen (50%, vs 20% in normal air) provides your body with such an oxygen overdose that you hallucinate). The co2 induced feeling of suffocation fucking hurts.

The end. Case closed. Please could killing creatures with co2 be outlawed and these threads can go away.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>4426867
>>4426870
I think so long as you're doing it in a way that works for low-pressure injection, it should work fine. Expecting the reaction-based ones to work with diffusers et al like pressurized bottles would be making it difficult.

https://youtu.be/rg1u-XVMU3Q?t=481
This would be the way to do it, IMO. All the CO2 is there and none of it is 'wasted' or fails to diffuse in time. You can change the diffusion rate by using a narrower bottle with less surface air, or increase it by using a larger bottle and place it near some turbulent flow.
With CO2 bottles there's 3 diffusion settings; too much, looks about right and the bottle is off - because filling a bottle is so cheap compared to the upfront cost that it's not really a concern as it would be with DIY where there is a lot more labour required.
Just my 2 cents.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
In reference to the OP, I recently had a power outage that lasted from 1am Saturday to 10pm Saturday. Apparently 10 inches of rain over 12 hours was too much for my end of the neighbourhood.

My "1500" UPS with 1 year old batteries unfortunately only lasted 7 hours and beeped at me enthusiastically around 8. I'd plugged a box fan into it last week because I was too lazy to find an extension cord. Would've lasted double that with only 2 canister filters and an air pump.
Ended up connecting the filters ass to mouth by splicing in a 12v DC pump run off a backup car battery and just used a couple powerbanks to power a pair of 5v USB water pump for surface turbulence in my smaller tanks.

I've got enough shit lying around that I could run everything off 12V in a roundabout way, but I'll be budgeting this year for some LiFePO4, MPPT charger and an inverter. Got a bunch of monocrystalline solar cells laying around that would work.

>>4426967
I'm one of the biggest over stockers on here I'd bet, but you should probably cull the platys down to 2-3 again. Take the rest to lfs or petco and they'll take them, won't give you anything likely but you don't have to kill them at least. Also probably need more filtration - it looks like you have a matten overflow, which has potential to be a very good filter, is the filtration section entirely packed with media?

Betta will definitely get some fry to slow the pop growth down the line, but crowntails are fucking slow so may not get all of them. I wouldn't expect it to actually kill any adult platys, just make the attempt now and again.

I'd also get some more plants, if I were you. Stem plants like anacharis or hornwort are super easy and fast growing, bolbitis ferns offer a nice contrast to the Java fern, anubias or buce are always easy and popular, etc. But you really would benefit from some more places for various fish to hide and to get away from each other.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>4428275
Ick spreads by spores falling off the infected fish while it swims around. With it being so infested its shedding spores constantly. With the treatment seemingly being effective on the other Tetras but not that one, it most likely has some kind of underlying issue that the others do not have. You are taking out any carbon you have in the tank right? it will absorb the meds out of the water.

How I see it you have 3 choices.

>Keep treating the whole tank and hope you are not stuck in an endless cycle.
Keep in mind that meds stress out fish. So even if you have fish that are not currently sick you might cause them to get sick by stressing them out.

>ISO the one/s that are in really bad shape and target treat them, while ensuring the main tank does not flare up again
Isoing a schooling fish is gonna stress it out alot, it might make it worse and maybe kill it faster, but it also wont be spreading quite so many spores to everything else.

>euthanize the sick fish.
You've given it and it's school the proper treatment. It's the only one that is not making noticeable improvement and is a risk of keeping the infection in the tank

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>4428263
Within gardening, at least in the US, the two are synonymous - one of the best composts sold locally is mostly lobster. In the context of walstad tank, the idea is to have the maximum starting level of nutrients in the substrate, plus the microfauna and bacteria that naturally come with it.

Basically, doesn't matter and either will work, just make sure it's entirely natural compost/soil without a bunch of long life chemicals as the source of nitrogen. And then let that bitch run for a couple months before you add anything but snails.

So I am pretty sure all those Pygmy Corydoras are dead except the one, at least 2 confirmed. Have only seen one since, and done a bunch of cleaning and looking. And then I had an ammonia spike that killed a puffer (which I didn’t find at first), changed 50%, thought I was good but the hiding pea body caused another smaller spike and then that killed one of my oldest khuli loaches.

Now I’m trying to figure out if that’s what really happened or if it was something else…if the pygmies died because my BB couldn’t handle three more puffers and 6 Pygmy Corydoras added at once or if they just failed to thrive or couldn’t handle my co2 injection or what.

I feel bad this poor little dude is all alone, but the other puffers don’t even bother him when he swims with them so I can’t imagine they decided to attack and that’s how I lost the previous ones.

Should I try to get him a school of friends or hold off for awhile in case something else is going on? I really wanted otos in the first place, but…

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>4430163
You need more filtration. If an ammonia spike lasts long enough to be measurable and harm fish, your filtration is inadequate, tautologically.

That said, I doubt the ammonia did it, the nitrite is really the only nitrogenous compound that can kill fish fast, particularly above 7ph.

If I were to guess, it was a combination of new pathogens in your tank vs the original water, stress from travel, and some nitrite/ammonia compounding the issue. The pH swings also probably contributed to weakened immune systems. Pygmies are also fairly fragile for corys, so those little impacts add up.

I'd increase filtration, either improving current volume or adding more, then eventually add some new friends for him if he makes it a few weeks. If he doesn't, I recommend habrosus corys instead, they're same size and stay on the bottom rather than swimming mid column, and are a little more hardy and a lot less shy.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>4430058
It's hard to believe this is not a troll post. On the off chance it's not:
1) Fish have long term memory. Most of us have fish that associate us with good things, primarily food. You're now training your fish to associate you with pain and stress, which will drastically decrease their overall lifespan and quality of life. Congrats.
2) Whatever forum you're going to is retarded and if this is not a troll post I question your intelligence for not immediately realizing this. Your clowns are definitely not the retarded ones in this scenario.
3) Clownfish do not NEED an anemone. I went to Maldives two years ago and swam with hundreds of clownfish: not a single anemone in sight. Clownfish in the wild can find shelter in a number of different things including rockwork and coral, this is perfectly natural. In tanks people have even gotten anemone to be hosted in fake anemone.
4) There are lots of different, far more effective, far less retarded, ways of encouraging hosting behavior. One surprisingly effective way is to tape a picture of clownfish being hosted by an anemone to the glass. Yes, they're smart enough to identify themselves and anemone in a picture, which makes you torturing them all the more insane. Two, you can use the tube method where you just get a big clear acrylic tube, put it over the anemone, and introduce (in your case re-introduce) the anemone to the tank in the tube. Finally, you could just wait. Sometimes it'll take months but it often happens on its own, and like I said, it's not necessary in the slightest.

>>4430243
More surface area is always good - sponges are the best media of those you noted but need to be cut to shape as otherwise it quickly clogs and water flows around rather than through, so at that point it's like putting large solid cubes in there. Ceramic rings/balls/etc have similar clogging issues, so I recommend stuff like the smallest bioballs (pic related not blown glass ones) or k1 micro - something small, high surface area, and that can't clog - but regardless of what you use, fill that bad boy to the brim.

Idk how often people say, but both no and yes. You should use a clamp or other means of securing the hoses beyond just sticking them on there. You should probably put the canister in a 5g bucket to be able to notice and catch small leaks, and place the intake and output high enough that a catastrophic leak can't drain the tank onto your floor. I've never had one break personally, but the damage in case of a failure would be far larger than an internal filter.

>>4430611
Idea: get some adult brine shrimp and feed them the medicine powder, put some aeration to keep it suspended in the water and then feed the brine shrimp to the fish. Brine shrimp just filter the water and will eat any algae even if it it toxic. (source on the information) https://journals.plos.org/plosone/article?id=10.1371/journal.pone.0175168
So they might eat the medicine if it is in the right particle size even if it kills them then feed it to the fishes as soon as possible so you will have medicine packed inside the brine shrimp. Also remember to remove the parasites from the aquarium once they are expelled.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>4431944
Depends on the glue.
Cyanoacrylate (superglue and all its various monikers) has been widely accepted as safe, as it hardens on contact with water.
Structurally, it's fine for small things like a lego construction to a rock, but perhaps not for the 20:1 scale leaning tower of rocks as the mechanical adhesion can be subverted over time by bacterial films or rock degradation between the two surfaces.

>>4426863
>why no hooved predators?

Paws/claws = scratch and grab. Think of cats and bears climbing onto things and dogs jumping and digging in; the same principles are applied when they hunt their respective prey animals (e.g. lions pouncing and grabbing antelope with their claws and mouth at the same time). Hooved predators would have to be crazy fast and have an insane jaw to compete - the fact so few of them existed kind of proves it's a losing formula. Entelodonts are the only ones I can think of off the top of my head.
